Aroma of roasted malts, tobacco,coffee,liquorice. Taste of coffee, roasted smoky malt, coffee, liquorice. Lovely.
Fra flaske på bryggeriet 3 Nov 12. Svart på farge. God sjokoladearoma. Smaken lakris & litt sjokolade. Holder seg uforandret. Søt, litt syrlig kaffe-ettersmak.

Almost no head, aroma of coffee and dark chocolate/cocoa. Full bodied, thick mouthfeel. Tastes like espresso and dark chocolate, with a sweet aftertaste like gummy bears or wine gums. A very nice stout.

Bottle courtesy of Saxo/HenrikSoegaard, 7%. Almost black with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, dusty, strong coffee and a little liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, little liquorice, medium bitter, medium sweet, dusty, little dark fruits, little leather, little oak and a little vanilla.

Dark beer with very little carbonation.  Big rich nose of burnt coffee and ash.  This is a full flavored beer with lots of bitter coffee, chocolate, campfire, ash, molasses, dried fruits, and lots of green hops.  Slick mouth feel and a long green coffee bean finish.  Very nice export stout.

Dark brown, almost black, with a big foamy light brown head,  fading slowly.  Nice green coffee notes hits first the nostrils,  burnt sugar and a bit of dark chocolates. Almost full body, lots of chocolate, silky palate, ending on a chocolate milk feeling. Very enjoyable stout.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Black colour. Heavy malty and moderate hoppy aroma. Heavy bitter wonderfull flavor. Smoke/roast/chocolate in perfect balance. Long heavy bitter finish. Creamy palate.

Bottle courtesy of Saxo/HenrikSoegaard. 7 % ABV. Black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and dark chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter. Smooth and soft. 211212
Bottle. Nice creamy head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich roast malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, caramel and hops. Full bodied.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2012 Bottled	07/12/12.  A black beer with a tiny grey head.  An exceptionally smooth stout with great roasty malts.  A fruity nose.  Roasty coffee.  Straight up delicious.  Score 4.3Subsequent rating scored 4.2  Score unaltered
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2013 bottle @ astral beers. It pours black and creamy with a thin brown head on top. Taste and flavor are liquorice, coffee and roast. Greatly balanced. A great beer.
A very drinkable yet interesting stout.  The 7.1 adds a bit of heat but this is well-balanced by an almost oatmeal mouthfeel and roasted aftertaste.  Well made.

Tasted from the bottle, @Kernel brewery, in July 2012.
Aroma is mild but proper.
Taste is excellent, like a classic proper stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
021212. Bottle from Kris Wines at hotel, London. Pours black with a small head. Aroma roasted malts, coffee. Dry dark malty rum like taste. Oily texture. Not Bad.

Deeply dark colour, thin brown head. Body is light to medium but taste is full and delicious. Roasted malts, coffee and liquorice above all.  Bitterness is low and shows up mainly in the aftertaste. Well balanced and pretty good brew!

33cl bottle. Black colour with a creamy and medium tan head, good lasting. Aroma is black coffee, licorice and roasty malts. Flavor has notes of black chocolate, dark coffee, strong licorice, roasted and toasted malts; also notes of red fruits are present. Dry and coffee final. Carbonation and body are medium. Texture is moderate oily.

Bottle (330 ml). Traded by SlovakSniper, thanks Patrick! Black with a small quickly diminishing beige head and little lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, rum, dark fruits, raisin and some smoked malt. Taste if of coffee, roasted malt, vanilla, rum and dark fruits with some hop bitterness. The description of the beer is accurate. Very good Foreign Stout. Good balance and really enjoyable!
Direi davvero una stout con le contropalle, aspetto nero impenetrabile, aroma delizioso di caffè e cioccolata. Anche in bocca fa la sua belle figura, bene...

33 cl bottle @ home. Pours dark brown with a small tan head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and liquorice. Flavour is roasted malt, coffee, liquorice, and bitter chocolate.

33cl bottle, pours a pours a pitch black with brown hinges and a light brown thick head with a soon dissipates. Aroma big bold simple flavours of coffee and chocolate some burnt caramel popcorn as you smell deeper, a lot more coffee on the taste little bit of bitter dark chocolate, a surprisingly thinner mouthful than I would have expected. Really good beer, big bold flavours done very well

via Beer Buddy

33cl bottle. Pours near pitch black with bubbly tan head and light lacing, Aroma is beautifully deep with coffee, plums, dark chocolate, dark roasted maltiness and a touch of liquorice combining beautifully. Taste follows suit but in a much more pronounced way; beautiful dark roast coffee notes mingle with dark booze-soaked fruits, bitter dark chocolate, roasted malt, slight smoke, light liquorice, brown sugar. Good Lord this is excellent. Slight alcohol warmth detected in the aftertaste, which is full of roasted, fruit, and coffee flavours. Lovely residual bitterness. Full and oily mouthfeel. Such a smooth piece of brewing. Take me back to 1890 lads, this is wonderful.

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2012. Pours a hazy and dark brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, roasted, slate and licorice. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is roasted with sweetness. Overall a really good beer. [Rating #3600]

Pours black with a small fully finishing brown head. The aroma immediately delivers roasted/burnt malts, strong coffee, some chocolate. In the mouth, coffee and malty taste are very intense. Creamy body, and a moderate bitter finish. Must eat something with a strong taste.

330ml Bottle from bottle-shop.co.uk 6.7% ABV
Big brown head, almost black colour. Strong aroma of chocolate and coffee right out of the bottle. Roasted malt, stinging hints of smoke/wood. 
Taste is malty with light heavy roasty bitterness, medium smoke, almost medium coffee. Dark chocolate. Light fruity. Massive indeed. Finish is rather simple, but enjoyable roasty bitterness with a pinch of smoky tartness. Very nice, I hope to have this again someday.It really calls for a juicy steak to go with.

Bottle from bottle-shop.co.uk.. 6.7 ABV. Very dark chestnut brown color with thick beige head. Roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, raisins in aroma. Taste, roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, rum, hints of dark fruit, alcohol. Roasted bitter finish. Lovely.

Bottle shared with Sarah during our last night in London. Pours near black with a dark brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a good amount of roasted malts with coffee and a hint of dark grains. Flavor starts with smooth dark grains that are joined by a hint of roasted malt and light pine.
Scura schiuma media buona persistenza tostaure intense caffe cioccola discreto corpo ma secca e buons beva leggere note caramellate buon amaro tostute intense

33 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK via Beer Ritz Leeds (I think). Very dark brown colour, nice dark tan head. Mixture of chocolate, prunes, soy sauce and spruce aroma. Thick, oily, heavy roasted malt transitions to a bittersweet chocolate and resin flavour, then a long hop fuelled finish.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2013 draught @ All in Beer Fest. Malty and coffee tones. Malt, coffee and bitterness. Medium to full body with a long, dry finish. 

On tap @ BBF 2012. Dark brown with a small brown head. Malty and roasted tones. Malt, fruit, coffee and bitterness. Medium to full body with a long balanced finish.

Bouteille de 330ml. BB 19.12.2013. version à 7,4% alc.  Un quasi gusher qui fit une belle couche de mousse brune. Le nez est de fruits fermentés, mais ce nest pas acide, il y a du chocolat avec du café. La bouche est rôtie, grillée, chocolaté. La finale est très torréfié, agréable et douce. La texture est bien définie. Lalcool est un peu présent. Un bon stout. 7+/10

Very black with a dense mocha coloured head. Roasted coffee, dark chocolate, liquourice, tobacco, dried dark fruits and a touch of vanilla on the nose. Bitter espresso, smoke, bourbon and leather in the taste. Burnt, bitter finish. Rich, thick and oily mouthfeel. Sumptuous.

At the Borefts 12. Poured a very dark brown color almost black. Aroma and taste were so freakin rich on this beer. Layers of leather, raisins, hops, vanilla bean, roasty coffee grind, and a little bit of dark cocoa. As it warmed up a bit some delicious dark fruits became evident. Thick mouth but smooth. Excellent beer.
Cask at @IndyManBeerCon dark brown well balanced malts with slight bitterness expresso coffee another great beer from The Kernel!

bottle   - almost black pour with thick tan head that stays and laces as a thin film . Big coffee and dark chocolate aroma  . taste is rich  - fresh roasted coffee with rich chocolate underneath rounding off in a nice espresso finish . medium carbonation  , oily texture   full mouthfeel . Quality stout
Cask @ Borefts 2012. Almost black. Roasted malt and chocolate in the aroma. Malty sweet roasty flavor with hints of coffee, chocolate and licorice. Sweet but complex and full of flavors.

The beer is black with an off-white head. The nose is quite heavy on the roasted malt but also has nice coffee and cocoa powder, and earthy hop notes. Light bitterness on the palate from the roasted malt and hops. A touch of earth, some coffee grounds, cocoa powder, and a good dark chocolate note.
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2014 On tap at Borefts. Fairly standard black colour with tan head. Aroma of roast malt, dark chocolate and coffee. lavour is similar with a dry aftertaste.
Black colour. Roasted malt aroma. Taste is a bit thick, malt roastiness and coffee, nice.

One of the best stouts I ever tired.
Super dark, thick, rich in aromas and flavors.                                
Coffee, chocolate,roasted malts...

Une bouteille de 33 cl qui doit être bue avant le 19.12.13.  Une robe bien noire pour ce liquide qui développe une mousse foncée remplie de beauté.  Au nez, une symphonie orchestrée par des malts rôtis et même légèrement brûlés.  Du café fraîchement moulu, du chocolat et des fruits foncés comme des solistes qui offrent un dialogue cohésif à leur chef.  Sur les papilles, la riche noirceur des céréales comme un concentré de saveurs lumineuses.  Des notes rôties, des fruits et du chocolat comme une oeuvre unique.  En bouche, un corps sculpté qui évolue avec allégresse et qui laisse, derrière son passage, une caresse douce et soyeuse.    Une finale pénétrante comme la fanfare dun grand ensemble poussé par la sagacité de ses multiples joueurs.
Thick mouth feel strong roasty chocolate coffee good lacing in the glass very smooth .
7.2% bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. Inky black with chocolate, liquorice, vanilla and whisky flavours with a creamy roasted coffee finish.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2014 Christmas present from future sister in law. Pours a dark colour, taste is of roast coffee and cola

33cl bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours opaque black with a nice crema head. The nose has dark chocolate and coffee. The taste has burnt dark chocolate with a slight smokiness. The palate is medium to full bodied with a dry texture and a very dry long finish. Overall, a dry stout, I think. Its good but cant get as excited as most of the other raters.

Black colour, beige head. Aroma of coffee, lots of coffee. Cocoa, roasted malts, caramel and light vanilla. Bitter coffee flavour, light sweetness, roasted malts. Creamy and full. Quite light finish, cocoa, mocha and chocolate.
(Sample from 33cL bottle @ GBF3, Gent)

Is now down to 6.7%.  Aroma has really deep burnt complex layers especially smoke and vanilla. Very oily feel with low carbonation. Flavour has lots of dark roasted malt with bitter coffee grinds and vanilla. 
Has a warming finish and lingering coffee bitterness.

Bottle at Craft Beer Co, 26/7/12. 7.2%. Pretty dry, roasty, light choc & light hop aroma. Taste - dry, milk choc, slight tangy hops, bit of soy, bit sour. Body is mid, quite lively on tongue; too lively for this stout, brings out sour flavours. Good for a historical recipe revival.

33 cl. bottle sampled @ GBF 2012 // black with a mocha head // smells is sweet, mocha, chocolate & chocolate pie, toffee, ice-cream, caramel // taste is sweet ice-cream, mocha, light roasted malts, milk chocolate, chocolate cakes and mouse with some light hops & bitterness in the finish, touch spices // very creamy // very good but maybe not as incredible as I was hoping, this still feels like it could be amped more, even fuller, even more ice-cream,... // reminds me somewhat of Thornbridge RIS both a recreations or attempts to do so of the original 19th century stout and I must say if stuff was like that back then, RIS might have even gone back a small step

Bottle.
Black, tan head. 
Coffee in aroma, lots of roasted malts.
Taste: Coffee, roasted malts, vanilla, chocolate, bitter finish. 
Outstanding beer from my favorite brewery.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2017 Bottle, gift from Andrew, and keg at Andrew Ushers and The Hanging Bat. Black body with a thin tan head that holds well. Good lacing. Aroma of chocolate mousse, cappuccino, ash, blackcurrant, wood and a hint of smoke. Flavour of concentrated flavours - dark chocolate, coffee, ash, roasted malt, prunes and cocoa powder. Dry finish. Medium body with a creamy texture. Soft fizz. Rich and tasty.
bottle at Euston tap, dark black pour with tan head. Well balanced notes of roast with very good flavor. coffee notes, chocolate, light vanila. Complex & delicious. Kernel rocks

Purchased from the brewery and consumed at home in Jan 12,  at 7.1% ABV.

Pours a rich black colour with a decent finger of creamy off-white head that soon vanishes becoming a small swirl mid glass with a thin layer around the edge.

Rich roasted malts on the nose, liquorice and burnt coffee/caramel and a crumble of chocolate.

Flavours pretty much match the nose, a fairly bitter blend of chocolate in the taste and spice also in the mix.

Mouthfeel is fairly full in body with a medium dry aftertaste.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
26/VII/2012 - 33cl bottle from The Bottle Shop (Canterbury) @ Klaas place - BB: 20/X/13 - (2012-760) 
Dark brown beer, small brown head, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots of mocha, caramel, dark chocolate, raisin bread, raisins. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: mocha in the start, dark chocolate, cocoa powder, some coffee, bitter hops. Aftertaste: coffee, dry hoppy ending, cocoa powder, ginger bread.

Bottle shared at tasting, thanks to Erickok.  Pours black with a small beige head.  Aroma of coffee, burnt malts and wood.  Flavour is heavy bitter and medium sweet with rich coffee and dark chocolate as well as a certain woodyness.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.  Lovely.
Loads of coffee, dry chocolate, roasted and milky. Bit of yeast. Very flavourful, especially because of the dryness? Coffee shot like aftertaste. Lingers for a long time. Nice! (At Deans Tasting)

35cl bottle shared.
Thin creamy tan head.  Coffee chocolate aroma.  Clear dark pour.  Yummy chocolate/coffee aftertaste.  A great brew!

330ml bottle pours after effervescent opening a dark black with creamy tan head. Smoky aroma, tobacco, leather, roasted cappuccino... very heady. Oily palate with liquorice, smoke. vanilla, wood tastes coming through which linger on for ages. Superb.

Pitch black body, dark brown head. Great aroma of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, burned toast. Full, almost syrupy body with little carbonation. Bitter flavour with coffee, dark chocolate, smoke and a hint of ash. Great.

Pours jet black with one finger of mocha head. Aromas of espresso, chocolate, earth. Aggressive bitterness, hints of tannins, rich chocolate and coffee. Its very rough and jagged, but in an agreeable way. Very good.

Bottle from Jackl.  Pours a nice dark brown/black color with a brown head.  Great roasty aroma with molasses, dark chocolate, prunes, raisins, asphalt in the nose.  Flavor is sweet and roasty, a welcomed bitterness finishes off a great robust brew.  Love the mix of roast, dark dried fruits and chocolate notes.
Super coffee beer.  Some chocolate to balance the coffee, both in the nose and the overall taste.  A sweetish beer, dark, and pure.  Tried with the parents in London in 2012.

My Bottom Line :  
Deeply chocolate-y malts benefit from some roasted angles and blackberry esters for a creamy Imperial Stout. 

Further Personal Perceptions :  
-A ring of foam circles the impenetrable darkness.
-This is beautifully aromatic.
-Light soy-like umami undertones are also found.
-The body is rich but never too heavy.

Bottle.

330ml bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring. Pours a deep chocolately brown with a chestnut glow, the head is billowing mocha to start, falling back to a thin covering; rich aroma of mocha and demerara sugar; really tasty and complex with sweet coffee, milk chocolate, red fruit, leather and tobacco; the finish is dry and gently warming. An excellent stout.

33cl bottle from the brewery. Pours a deep brown colour with two fingers of beige head. Aroma is espresso, coffee beans, roasted malts. Taste is a flavor explosion, with dark chocolate, loads of coffe roasted notes, wood, vanilla. Moderately bitter with a touch of acidic to the finish. Mouthfeel is medium to full with good carbonation. Overall, complex and balanced at the same time.
Pours black with lasting thin mocha head. Rich, mocha aroma, then alcohol. medium bitter. Roast caramel and coffee... nice linger on tongue
Cask at The Southern. Black with a tan head. Dense roasted character. Cold coffee and burnt toast. Smoke and lots of black chocolate. Very characterful. Delicous.

From the bottle, a fine London export stout. Pours black, good head on it at first. Distinct coffee and chocolate aroma. Has all the rich coffee tastes you expect from a stout but with espresso like bitterness. I might even get poncy and suggest theres some tobacco in the mix of flavours as well. Really dry bitter stout. Excellent stuff and one to look out for.

Bottle from The BottleShop-Canterbury
Pours dark brown with a beige foam head. Tobacco, molasses and very dry. long lingering finish.

#1426 draught; nose is decent cola, weak hazel, some earth, leather, later roasted malt, feel is mediumwatery, carb is medium, taste is  sour leaves, stale coffee, thin iron, roasted malt, bread, late chlorine note

0.33l bottle from beermerchants.com The pour on this one is damn near black. Some dark brown traces around the edges, but other than that, this is classified as a black beer. It also has a small quickly sidesticking tan head. Hard to describe the aroma on this one. Its actually kinda old - like in a old mans couch, only in a good way. Its of course strong and powerful with heavy roasted - almost burned malts, it has a ashy touch, I also find traces of both cardboard and cereal box - like after the cereals are gone. Sounds really strange, but I like it. When tasting it its really one of those beers that just glides down the throat way to fast, and when its gone some seconds you get this great roasted - almost burned and lots of dark bitter Belgian chocolate in the finish and aftertaste. Theres also traces of cold coffee, and it has a mild subtle acidity from the roasted malts. Yeah, I like this! 22.03.2012
Bottle from beermerchants.com. Tasty, really dark and lots of dark flavours. Chocolate, coffee, all that jazz.

Pours a dark brown slightly hazy. Aroma of chocolate, smoke and tobacco. Taste is intensified. This is soo nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a pitch black color with a dark brown color. Vanilla, molasses, charcoal and bitter chocolate hit the nose. Smooth rounded mouth with nice roasted malt character, but a touch of sweetness. Dark fruits and molasses dance over vanilla. Moderately bitter lingering finish with notes of charcoal and vanilla. Very balanced. Very well made. Alcohol well hidden. The perfect beer to wait out a once-every-50yr storm - and that is just what I am doing.

Bottle. Aroma deep and roasty, malts, coffee, molasse.
Flavour is very dry and roasty malt, chocolate, coffee and more. Good stuff.
Bottle. Black pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is roasty, yeasty, coffee, chocolate and spices. Flavor is thick roasted malts, bready yeast and bitter spices. Nice balance and thick body. Great brew.
Bottle. Black with tiny head. Raisin and coffee aroma. Flavour is liquorice, leather, dark fruit and coffee with a heavy bitter finish. A little smoke too. Complex and interesting.
Bottle 0,33ltr: Opaque black brew with an heavy dry bitter taste like coffee, chocolade and dried fruits in an great way, this one is 7,5% strong. But the label is rather dull, beer is great.

Kleur is zwart, ruikt naar koffiebonen en ruikt naar een koffiepak, Smaakt naar mokka, pure chocolade. Ik vind het veel te sterk, ook al lijkt het begin waterig daarna komt pas de smaakexplosie. Ik kreeg er kippenvel van, de smaak bleef ook nog eens heel lang hangen.

Bottle:
Small light brown tan ish bubbly head which changes into a lacing on the side as an open ring. Black beer with a deep dark brown edge.
Smell lots of coffee, roasted malts and roasted coffee.
Taste coffee, roasted coffee, espresso, roasted espresso, roasted nice good bitter, hint of vanilla and slight hints of pencil and dark bitter chocolate.
Deep, lots and loads of coffee and roasts in the taste. Good!
Good bitter roasted coffee herby aftertaste.
Low carbo, soft mouthfeel, full body and a watery texture.
Damn this is some good stuff!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle in London. Black beer with a creamy beige head. Cocoa aroma, chocolate, coffee notes, rosted, earthy, milky notes. Cocoa and coffee flavor, rather bitter, soot, roasted, some tar, licorice, vinous notes.

Bottle at the brewery. Jet black with small golden head. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, touch of dark fruitiness. Taste is roasted malt, bitter finish, bit of booze, touch of liquorice along with the expected coffee, and vanilla. Very nice!
Bottle. Black, foamy tan head. Herbal, coffee nose with mocha hints. Vanilla malt flavours and vegetal hops combine with an almost coconut edge. Damn lovely beer.

Bottle from the brewery. Black color with a small tan head. The aromas of dried fruit, smoke, some brown sugar. The taste is actually quite hoppy, some espresso, bitter chocolate. The bodys medium, oily. Dry. Overall, a very drinkable stout indeed. Straightforward and tasty.
nice coffee flavour,also like good espresso .hints of raisin . poor head retention ,but good carbonation .

Bottle at home, 13th January 2012. This followed a Kernel IPA Citra, so a good Beer Friday. Aroma is dark chocolate and coffee, pours to reveal a nice black drink, taste is hoppy with bitter chocolate, and coffee, palate is perfect oily and smooth. I would choose the Kernel Imperial Brown Stout over this, but it is close

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2015 Rerate, bottle from Slijterij van Pernis. Lots of coffee and chocolate, with a bit of vanilla and mocha. Great stuff. + .7


Bottle @ Brewdog Glasgow. Black colour, beige head. Nose is full chocolate, roasted malts, maybe bit of mocha, bit salty. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, liquorice. Quite odd. Medium bodied.

Bottle @ BrewDog Glasgow. Dark brown almost black colour, no head. Unusual flowery biscuit flavour. Strong spicy fruity flavour. Quite smooth. Needs to be drunk slowly. Not a big stout fan but I like this one.

Bottle conditioned @ 7.1%. Lively, with a tan head with zero retention. Jet black body. Chocolate, roast, washing up liquid, fruity, nutty. Bittersweet. Long bitter finish. Fizzy, Quite soft, refreshing, rejuvenating.

Wow first sip packs a hoppy punch. Very dark roasty oily chocolaty syrup. Has an intense brown head which lingers. Taste is very heavy and filling with a bitter clean finish. However little disappointed with aroma for such an amazing beer I expected more intense aromas, but smell isnt very strong. But overall an absolutely beautiful beer.

33cl bottle from DeMolen biershop.
Brune foncée, col crémeux moka.
Arôme a une pointe aigre lactique le tout suivi par une note café malt chocolat.
En bouche, une bière aux notes chocolat amer et encore je note ce profile lactique et aigre, le tout sur un malt épais grillé et un pointe fruité noire. Retrouve ce style de stout anglais ayant une touche de cuire avec une once de malt fumé et de café froid. Fini est sec et grains. Fini conserve un brin damertume houblonnée.

Bottle at 7.1%. Black with a beige head.  Aromas are coffee, dark chocolate and liquorice with mellow blackberry.  Floral with grapefruit and leather.  Oily with hints of marzipan and peppery notes.  Flavours are rich coffee with dark winter fruit and gritty, bitter dark chocolate.  Dark rum with cola.  Pithy bittersweet grapefruit with a yeasty, dry, woody finish.  Very good.

In bottle. Pours a dark brown colour with a ruby tinge and a thin tan head. Aroma of chocolate milk, some grassy hops, caramel and alcohol. Big roasty malt and chocolate flavours with pine and grassy hops to finish, Alcohol is well balanced and roasty malt lingers. Moderate carbonation and light CO2 prickle.

Bottle @ BrewDog Aberdeen,
Black, dark tan head dissipates to thin layer, good lacing.
Aroma - roasted malt, sweet chocolate, espresso, dark fruit berries, sweet malts, molasses.
Taste - coffee, roasted malts, sweet sweet dark malts, chocolate, tasty, well blended but not too complex. Alcohol quite well hidden.
Palate - soft carb, full body, sweet syrupy sticky texture, smooth.
Overall - Good stout, good flavour, but a bit too sweet.

Bottle: Literally black, stable brownish foamy layer, roasty-bitter aroma, vanilla, dried fruits and wood in the nose; moderate to solid bitter-sweet flavour, a slight acidity is present as well, medium bodied, very smooth; roasty-bitter and coffeeish finish, warming alcohol detectable. Gorgeous british brew
About as good as a beer can be.  Powerful liquourice/coffee taste. Long mouthfeel. The brewer should be given a medal!

33cl Bottle from De Bierkoning, ABV 7.5%. Black, brown head. Aroma of lovely fresh coffee, moccha, bitter chocolate, rum. Flavour is hard hard roasted malts, tar, coffee, rum, espresso, coffee, light dark fruits, herbal (all like in the descreption indeed) bitterness, very hard roasted bitter finish. Medium bodied. Aroma promises more than flavour delivers, but nice nevertheless.

For late celebration of Thursday, which was International Stout day, and the day when my first Linux Kernel patch was accepted to mainline. This beer should be the most accurate celebration drink to me what comes to the Nov 3rd, 2011.

The drink seems to be very stout like; black, short light brown thick head, roast smell of smoke and coffee. First taste is sweet, and very malty. Bit later there is plenty of aromas. Mostly heavy malts, some basement/leather/earth and soy sauce with cooked vegetables. Finish is unsurprisingly long. The creamy texture and flat carbonation makes the feel of this drink very good. Overall a good, good stout.
Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Smells good, looks fantastic. Taste is, ooh, wow, so smooth, rich and mocha-y. Deep, long, vibrato balance of sweet, dry and power. Really fine.
Bottle: Black with a small head. Aroma is coffee and roasted malt. Flavor is inetnsive and full bodied, notes of roasted/burnt malt, dark coffee and molasse. Roast bitter finish. Lovely.

Cask at CASK Pub & Kitchen Pre-GBBF Meet the brewer event, London. Opaque black color. Sweet and roasty with chocolate, licorice, coffee, toffee and nuts. Fairly coffeish, more sweet than bitter. Nice to have this on cask, I think it gives this an extra kick.
From bottle. Black with tan head. Big aroma, smoke, toast, char, lots of roast malt. Taste is similar. Quite hard to drink, not very smooth. Tastes burnt

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2012 Cask. Black with a small off-white head. Malty aroma with licorice, molasses and dark chocolate. Sweetish roasted flavour with licorice and chocolate. Rich and full-flavoured, but a bit too one-dimensional licorice/roast for my taste. Rating: 3.4
Kegged at Boreft Beer Festival 2012. Chocolate, dried fruit and sweet cherry dominate the aroma. Sweetish flavour of dark chocolate, roasted malt and dried fruit.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2012 Bottle from Great Grog. Very dark brown, almost black, thin tan lacing. Dirt, coffee, some herbal notes on the nose. Hint of rum and raisin warmth. Palate is largely dry and bitter chocolate, but with some sweet raisin, bags of rich deep dark cocoa malts. Bitter slightly herbal hop finish. Velvety mouthfeel, really tasty stuff! Also sampled off keg at BrewDog - slightly more sweetness, slightly better mouthfeel. Extra point.

Draught @ Stone vs Moeder Lambic event in Brussels. Again, thank you Jean for letting me and my friends have a bottle of this. Opague, pitch black colour with a light brown head. Smells mocca, coffee, bitter, chocolate, bourbon - in a quite overwhelming fashion. So full of flavours.. Tastes mocca, sweet, icecream, vanilla, coffee, roasty. Its almost a dessert. This beer is crazy. Very full body, bit thick, tasty.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 330ml bottle.  Pours near pitch black with a small head.  Aroma is coffee with a little smoked ham.  Taste has roast and yeast to start.  Bitter coffee and meaty finish.  Very oily in the mouth.  3.7

330ml bottle.  Best before 19/12/13.  Pours pitch black with no head.  Aroma is coffee, liquorice, soy sauce and smoked ham.  Taste has liquorice and coffee to start.  Dark berries and chocolate on the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2013 33cl, at 7.2%Vol, new exclusive English brew Anno 2010, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Stout, roasted and slightly smoked/alcoholic, heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!

33 cL bottle into a Westmalle glass.  Very little head, disappears quickly, over a black beer.  The aroma is fantastic, chocolate and coffee, dark malt, delicious.  Tastes lovely, chocolate, sweet with body and a hint of coffee and a bit of bitterness, nice and complex.  One of the best of British.  Really good beer, proud its UK.

Bottle at Chez Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Gift from Jean, huge thanks! Almost pitch black opaque color, but some dark red comes though when held into a light. No head, just a small light brown lacing. Smell so much coffee, mocca and caramel, but mostly its mocca. Taste malts, bitter, coffee, mocca and chocolate. Bitter aftertaste, slightly oily texture. Very round velvety taste. Soft carbo, medium body.

Black beer with fluffy tan-cream head. Peanuts, coffee, Indonesian satesauce and moccha. Vinous, stout-like acidity, other grains, roasted barley, grapeskins in the aftertaste. Very well-bodied, thick, viscous. Now theres some stout. If this is from a historic recipe, it beats most of those recreations hands-down.  Grand merci à Jean H.!
shared at Max & Jesss  - dark brown pour, toasted and smoked malts and bready. Milk chocolate and nuts. Dark fruits and dries out into woody finish.

Half pint, cask, 7.8% abv, at Meet the Brewer event at Cask Pub & Kitchen, Pimlico. Oily dark pour. Bright naked surface. Aroma of sweet cocoa with a hint of lactose to it. Milk chocolate in flavour supported by notes dried fruits and rum offset by a moderate tart and bitter ending. Enjoyable (London, 01.08.2011).

August 13, 2011 - draught at The Kernel (south and east of Tower Bridge).  Opaque brown-black with a creamy, lasting, slightly green-tinged light brown head with thick lacing.  Aroma is lush - fresh non-acidic coffee roast, a little cream and mint tossed in, very light chocolate and "dark" fruit (7+).  Taste follows, also has a hint of mineral grittiness which knocks down the incipient sweetness from the coffee/chocolate roast - alcohol is incredibly restrained, really nicely balanced all-round when you start to detect light peat, herbal/floral bitterness and even some random oak tannin as it warms.  Creamy and thick mouthfeel, a bit airy, the alcohol emerges slightly in the bitter, slightly earthy roast coffee bean finish.  Really, reallly good stuff, these guys make the real deal from what I have tried so far!

At a tasting, thanks Oren, pour black to brown with a brownish head, aroma of smoke, milk chocolate, milk, brandy and nuts, flavor is dry with some bitterness (not from hops), malt acids, lactic acids, coffee and tender smokiness, medium to full bodied, great

Bottle at a tasting. Thanks Oren. Black-colored with a big of brown foam. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and some liqueur notes. Flavor of bitter chocolate, roasted malt, light acidic notes, a bit of fruitiness and a slightly drier finish. Medium to full-bodied with a flat but silky mouthfeel.

Cask at Cask Pub & Kitchen @ Pre-GBBF Kernel night. Pitch black - offwhite head. Nice sticky body, fruity, coffee, ok hoppy, exotic fruits, fullbodied, sweetness, herbal, light flowery, dried fruits, alcoholic, raisins, light smokey. Lovely.

330 ml bottle. dark brown with mini mocha head. intense aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee. rich flavor of highly roasted malts (with its acidity), and dark dried fruits (carobs). very long after taste, light to medium body. very good beer.

Kernel Event @ Cask Pub and Kitchen, 1 August, 2011.  Cask. Pours brown with a small head and lacings. Roast, caramel, smoke and liquorice. Smooth and full bodied. Velvetly soft. Dry roasted end. Lovely!

330ml bottle from Utobeer, 7.8%, drunk at home, 27th Dec 2010. Black with a small beige head. Perfumed roasty nose. Tar, shoe polish, leather on the tongue. Great mouthfeel - strength without heaviness, smooth without excessive oiliness. A very drinkable strong stout. Lovely balance of good hops and good malts.

Cask @ pre GBBF 2011. A black colored beer, with a small beige head. The aroma of coffee malt, bitter with hints of chocolate. The taste of coffee with dark fruits, some sweet with notes of bitter. Aftertaste some sweet with bitter.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2011 From the cask at CPK, Kernal event. Sweet, choco, tangy and hoppy too. Tingy, peppery finish nice.
Nice body, fruity, berries, rather sweet.

Bottled 500ml (PBF, BBE 2012)
Opaque black color, small beige head. Strong aroma of licorice, coffee, coffee beans. Medium-bodied. Quite easy to drink for this ABV. Licorice, coffee beans, roasted malty. Pleasant stout. Not too burned!

Bottled (from the Kernel, London). Black colour, small brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts, mild toast as well as some liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, some ashes as well as mild liquorice and mild grassyness. Also some quite vanillaish notes.

Bottle at the Rake in London. Pours  a black creamy, bubbly lacing. Aroma is cappucino, and strong dark chocolate. Mouthfeel is creamy with notes of bitter malts, coffee, roast, smoke, tobacco, espresso.

From bottle on 26 April 2011. Very dark brown. Slightly oily consistency. Extremely roasty, verging on burnt, with lots of chocolate and hints of pruney fruit. Plenty of tangy hops too. Firm, rich mouthfeel. Excellent stuff.
Bottled.  Very black, beige head. Aroma of licorice and tobacco. Dryish with meaty full body, clean, rounded mouthfeel. Plenty of dark chocolate, notes of smoke. Salty salmiak finish. Quite intense.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2012 Bottle from the Kernel Brewery. Lovely liquid black in the glass with a chocolate tan head that dissolves after a minute or so. Rainbow bubbles in the foam. Nose is deep beautiful chocolate syrup and then black coffee notes. Bit soapy. Flavour is silky chocolate syrup sauce. Fairly light in texture for a stout although body is robust and full. Bit of roasted bitterness on the finish. This is a very fine beer. Re-rate - one year on and this is still a great beer. Moves up a point for me. From 4.3 to 4.4.

330 ml bottle in England. Pours black with a dark tan head. Loads of coffee and chocolate on the aroma and some raspberry. taste is much the same. On the palate there is lots of roast malt, giving flavours of coffee and milk chocolate, then a smoky, chared and very soft dry finish. Excellent.

330 ml bottle conditioned, bought at The Cheese & Wine Shop, Darlington. ABV is 7.7%. Pitch black colour, big to moderate brown head. Roasty aroma with strong notes of coffee, hints of liquorice and ashes. The flavour is roasty and quite dry, again strong notes of coffee, hints of liquorice and dark bitter chocolate. Good stuff.

Didnt get a big sample of this but it was pretty good. Poured dark brown, aromas of toasted malt, chocolate, smoke, wood. Very smooth with lots of chocolate on the palate. Finish is roasted malt and chocolate. Quite enjoyable.

Bottle at Max and Jesss place.  Pours a hazy and murky brown with a thin beige head.  Roast, chocolate and cocoa, vanilla and malt, roast and chocolate.  Smooth and sweet, roast, and chocolate.  Lots of roast and chocolate on the finish.

Tasting at MaxxDaddys house.  The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt.  Very nice.  The flavor is the exact same.  The appearance is the usual deep black, light tan head.  Medium in body, light for this style. Really good.

Bottle from beermerchants.com A black coloured pour with a medium beige head on top. Good roasty, malty aroma. Tastes malty, chocolate, coffee, dry, slight bitterness. A superb stout from London. Kernel are currently knocking out some of the best beers in England.
Bottle at Maxs tasting. Pours near black with a beige head. Dry roasted malt aroma with a hint of coffee. The flavor has dry roasted malts and a light sweetness. Really good.
Bottle shared by Mario at Maxs tasting. Pours black. Tan head. Nose and taste of dry chocolate malts, roasted coffee and vanilla. Dryish finish.

Bottle, bought @ Beermerchants.com.
Deep black with a smallish, creamy, light-brown head. Fizzes slowly away. Aroma is lovely, overall sweet, with some good chocolate, light cocoa, mildly roasted, light liqourice. Medium carbonation, good creamy and light dry mouthfeel. Flavour is very lovely, good chocolate and liqourice as base with some good grassy hops, mild coffee, well roasted. Light vinious with some fair hoppy bitterness. Very nice.

Bottle from the brewery. Near black in colour with no head. Plain chocolate aroma with some roasted, slightly creamy malts. Flavour had black coffee and more chocolate. Slightly oily mouth feel, coating the mouth and leading to a bitter finish with a touch of warming alcohol.

Bottle from Beermerchants.com. Pours black with a 1 inch dark brown head
Aroma of strong dark bitter and sweet chocolate, also some coffee and liquorice. Taste is medium sweet, smooth and light roasted malts, slightly burnt, with liquorice playing in the background. Ends with a moderate spicy bitterness, quite good this one.

Bottle from Beermerchants. Poured virtually black with a good sized beige head and some lace action. Nose was enticingly laden with malt, dark chocolate and coffee. Quite fullish mouthfeel, slid down soft and smooth Top notch flavour jam packed with roasty goodness and coffee aplenty. Alcohol nicely smothered. Bitterness levels started to pick up towards the finish. Superbly well executed stout.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2015 330ml bottle (Utobeer, London)
6+ Very rich roasty aroma, touch of chocolate. Anna thought she got some banana (poured without any sediment, for reference).
5- Beautiful black body, tight tan head.
7 Moderately full roasty taste, some sour stale coffee notes, and a good dry bitterness too. But perhaps a little sludgy and cocoa-powdery.
4 Full smooth rich palate, not slick, carbonation low. Slightly chocolatey finish, some nice bitter hops too. Doesnt completely cover the alcohol, but it doesnt exactly feel strong either.
13 I liked it more than Anna, who would have given it a little bit less everywhere. She should get her own account. If they could rein in the cocoa-powder sludginess, I think it would be great.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (6-:4:6:4:13=3.3-) - shared by vastaktiv and rosenberg - thanks!
Do I get an enteric component to the aroma? simple roast in aroma. fairly simple everywhere, in fact. just a roasty brew, not really with any highlights.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Pudel, Tallinn) (8-:4:7+:4:15-=3.8-)
Gorgeous chocolatey roast aroma. Great rich roasty palate. Just a great stout, no weak spots at all. No idea what was up with the previous two.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 Pours thick and slick and oily with a depleting tan head. I found the aroma rather unleasent, a sort of damp feet woody smell. Good carbonation. The flavour is full dry coffee with plenty of chocolate.

Previous rating is obvious none-sense. Had a bottle of this again at Brew Wharf last night and it was fantastic. Aroma was dark fruits choc and mellow roast. Full bodied and delicious.

Bottle from Beermerchants. Deep oily pour with a fine, dissipating tan collar. Aroma: apples rolled in ash, mouldering leaves, cranberry, Crunchie, toast. Drinks a bit like a concentrate of the London Porter; thick and mellow with Twiglet and dark chocolate praline notes; mouldering leaves, coal smoke, dabs of brine, black cherry. Nice powdery cocoa, cigar linger. Solidly roasted stout that carries the alcohol with some finesse.

(Bottle, purchased at the brewery outlet, Druid Street, London) Pitch black colour with frothy, pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with chocolate, black coffee, cocoa, ashes and hints of liquorice and tobacco. Malty, roasted taste with notes of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, hints of tobacco and dark berries. A touch of cream. Well pronounced but rather gentle cocoa bitterness in the finish. Lots of chocolate truffles with cocoa powder. More than medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Smooth and velvety mouthfeel. Exceptionally well balanced and very tasty. Lovely beer.

Bottle (conditioned). Smells of coffee beans and liquorish. Black with a hint of cherry colouring.  Strong coffee flavours with liquorish finish. Hint of tangy cooking apple, hint of bitter cherry. Warming alcoholic burn on finish along with bitter liquorish.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2015 bottle at home ... deep black ... thin tan head ... soft chocolate ... light meaty ... nose  ... light bitter chocolate ... soft burnt tone in background ... nice 3.7

tap at brewdog ... deep black ... thin lacing ... soft dry dark roast malt nose ... dark malts ... light bitter charcoal roast ... litle chocolate ... quite dry ... nice if a little dry and little bitter for me 3.8

tap at the southern ... deep black ... thin tan head ... soft sweet roast ... juicy malts ... deep blackcurrant ... soft sweet toffee malts ... light fruity chocolate 3.8

Bottle at home ... deep black ... thin tan lacing ... soft mellow sweet coffee roast nose... soft roast ... little thin in body ... dark chocolate and coffee ... soft dark fruits ... nice but not the one id have chossen for the Jamie and Jimmy Food fight.... quite a lot of ovaltine in the linger ... im sticking at 3.8

Keg at hanging bat.. Deep black.. Thinest tan lacing... Soft dark blackcurrant roast.. Soft chocolate roast malts nose... Dark sweet chocolate roast.. Jammy roast chocolate roast... Dark sweet chocolate roast 4.0

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty chocolate and licorice aroma. Roasted malty chocolate flavor with hints of licorice and caramel. Has a roasted malty chocolate finish with hints of licorice in the aftertaste.

Bottle at The Rake.  Pitch black. Lasting thin beige head. I like Export stouts.  Lovely tar and cocoa really rich. Outstanding aroma. Rich full in mouth. Like thick liquid chocolate. Bit of grainyness on finish adds some dryness to the dry feel. Touch of tar liquorice. Amazing really. Just stunned me.

Pours black black with a brown thick head leaving nice lacing. Aroma is smokey and salty, heavy of roasted malts, some hints of coffee and chocolate and dark fruits. Nice body; not too heavy nor too thin. Good stouty mouthfeel. Flavor is slightly acidy, fresh yet heavy stouty with some smokey saltiness and tones of fresh fruits. Lean, bready and heavy palate. Finishes with a longlived smokey, tartbitter hoppy aftertaste. Excellent.

Bottle in a hotel room in London.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Roasted aroma of liquorice and dark chocolate with notes of dried fruits.
Roasted flavour of liquorice and caramel with notes of dried fruits.
Roasted finish.

20th November 2010.  Opaque black stout, good tan head. Crispish dry palate. Minerally dark malt and bitter coffee. Trace of cream and a whisper of orangey hop fruit. Dry crisp fresh finish. The fresh crisp palate elevates this stout out of the odinary.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2011 33 cl bottle from Mennos place.  Nearly black, thin brown head that settles quickly to an edge.  Aroma of burnt espresso and dark cocoa.  Taste is dark roasted coffee, bitter cocoa.  Finish is very bitter.  Decent body.  Could use a slight throttle back of the bittering hops, but otherwise a very nice stout.

Bottle that I picked up at the Kernel Brewery, Bermondsey, London, consumed at home on Lozs birthday 14.11.10   Pours black with a light beige head. This is lovely in the mouth, soft, velvety and smooth. Light creamy coffee, touch dry but also with a good roasty sweetness. Quite lovely.  A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15  3.8

Milk chocolate and coffee in the nose,  a hint of smoke and some cherries. Very dark with beige head.
Lovely flavour of roasted grain, campfire sourness and a clean crisp finish. Lingering cigarette ash in the aftertaste.
A very welcome beer from a new brewery, hope you keep up the standard!
(Bottle from beermerchants)

[330ml bottle, Kernel Brewery, London] Much darker pour than the London porter  as youd expect  thick, treacle-like consistency. Touch of coffee on the aroma, but mostly heavy bitter alcohol and stewed fruit. An exceptionally well-crafted strong stout  bitter coffee with a warming alcohol aftertaste and more bitterness on the finish. However, it never oversteps the mark  its not too bitter at the end, its not too punchy with the alcohol, and the smooth sweetness yields just at the right time. Rivals the best US imperials in every way [06102010]

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2015 Bottle at the London Brewers Showcase. Pours opaque brown with a strong, tan head. Holds a sharp malt aroma with some roast and dark cocoa. Lightly sweet with some unique flavors and notes of earth, tobacco, licorice and some chocolate. Medium to full in body with average carbonation and light warmth. Finishes with lingering roast and some nice bitterness. (September 2010, score: 3.8)Bottle at home in London - picked up at the brewery. Pours rich black with a dense, frothy mocha head. The aroma is rife with burnt, ashy roast, dark chocolate and dark berries and cherries. Medium sweet flavor with pleasant sticky burnt sugars, some dry charcoal, strong roast and bittersweet dark chocolate, bitter scorched earth. Medium to full bodied with massaging carbonation and velvety texture. Robust but still exceedingly well balanced in the finish, with overarching and lingering baking cocoa, some more liquid chocolate elements, scorched earth, dried dark fruits, some burnt marshmallows. Great layering and complexity to this one. Outstanding beer, worthy of its reputation. (August 2015, score: 4.2)

Pours black as squid ink with only the very edges finding any colour.  The head is medium tan with a layer of creamy white on top - I love these two tier heads.  The lacing is lasting and easily reinvigorated.  The nose is of roasted malts, aged hops, dark chocolate and fortified red wine.  The mouth brings a orange edge to the chocolate.  Then come coffee, leather, tobacco and a mild yeast presence.  It finishes on the roasted characters, with the hops growing progressively bitter towards its final dry end.  A well done stout and highly enjoyable.

330 ml bottle at home: pours black with tall somewhat tight tan head. Fades to a thick film. Roast barley, toast and a good underlying malt nose. Green herbal notes come up as the beer sits. Sweet alcohol and a touch of toffee mix with a light mixed nut aroma. In the mouth you first get green herbal hops and then the roast. Roast goes nice and deep but not astringent. Sweet alcohol comes in with a touch of treacle. At first I actually think there is too much hop but the extra hop comes in handy as you get further into the beer. Medium body which ends just dry enough to be very drinkable.

Thanks! Opaque black body, topped by mediumsized, creamy tan head. Big chocolatey malt aroma. Some fruitiness,  and notes of licorice and freshly crushed coffee beans. Initial taste is gently sweet with a strong malt body. More chocolate, roastedness and licorice. Also a tone of light acidulous fruitiness. Noticable hop bitterness in the backbone. Mouthfeel is slick. Roast, peppery bitterness and a fine dryness in the ending. A very good Stout.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2010 Bottle at the Rake. Pours black with a dark tan head. Loads of coffee and chocolate on the nose, plus notes of sour apple, pepper and raspberry. On the palate there is lots of roast malt, giving flavours of coffee and milk chocolate, then a smoky, dry and very bitter finish. Excellent.
Dark brown with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Sweet flavor with hard roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and hops. Finished dry and bitter.

33 cL bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malt and liqourice. Mild smoked like touch. Dark roasted malt and liqourice. Lingering dark malty and vague overripe fruity. Lasting roasted to smoked note into the far finish.

Bottled. A black beer with a thick brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and a bit of alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of roasted malt, dark chocolate, alcohol, and sugar, leading to a dry and quite roasted finish.

Bottle 33 cl. Courtesy of fonefan. Pours an opaque black with a dense light brown head. Lots of fat burned malts and licorice. Solid body, hard roasted oily malts and licorice - lots of licorice. Very malt bitter finish. Very well crafted. 010910

Bottle from Kris Wines. Almost black underneath a huge, light brown head. The nose promises a decent chocolate and espresso attack, like a good caffe mocca. Flavours start very chocolatey, moves on to include, is there even a mildening (original or strange) perfumey touch towards the end? Body can easily be fuller, but that does not ruin the overall impression: The Kernel goes from strength to strength.

Bottle 330ml.Clear dark black brown color with a average to large, frothy to creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is light heavy malty, chocolate, coffee, dark malt. Flavor is light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, hoppy, dark roasted. Body is medium full, texture is oily and sticky, carbonation is soft. [20100731]
Dark brown, with a thick tan head.  Smells like a pretty standard stout, with a hint of coffee mixed in there.  Taste has a hint of coffee as well.  Smooth, with a slightly bitter finish.

330ml bottle from Kernel Brewery. Pours dark brown with a thin caramel head. Nose; fresh roasted coffee, caramel, soy sauce and sesame oil. Taste; coffee, bitter-sweet, caramel, over-powering soy sauce and sesame oil with a very long finish. Like the smell, but found the taste too rich and difficult to drink much. I couldnt really get over the strong soy-sauce taste to enjoy it.

Bottle from Mr Lawrence Wine Merchants, Brockley. Pours black with a tan head. Very nice coffee and dark chocolate aromas. A little bit of vanilla in there too.  Severe coffee attack on the palate. Smoother than Raymond Delorney (School for Scoundrels). Roasty, malty finish. The Kernels Mustard!! Damn fine brew!

A Mes rate. Bottle thanks muchly to Nate.Woo hoo, another bloody good Kernel beer. Almost opaque black red with a really impressive beige head and lace. Stunning coffee and malt aroma with a surprising amount of roasty and toasty character. Flavour wise, my god, this is really good. Massively roasty and gloriously rich. Superb malt, some leather and tar, faint rubber, and erm... Coffee. Loads of it. Utterly brilliant stuff. English in style through and through but just ramped up a little. Really good length, the coffee just will not shift, it just hangs around making you want more. Stellar stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2010 What a stonker from Evin! Fantastic job mate. Awesome head which calms down to fill out half the top surface. Lacing is good. The creamy guey dark brown head matches the label exceptionally well. Roasted malts; espresso and faint grains on aroma. Taste is nutty chocolate, roasted mals, burnt toast, espresso, vanilla, oak and an injection of cream. A stunning authentic English ale. Thanks a lot Evin. Based on a recipee from 1890. Edit - Fresh at the brewery and its even better! 4.3.
